senses.de: The money earned for work done, typically paid on a weekly or monthly basis
senses.ex: Because of your extra hours, your wage this month is much higher

Tips.title: Payment Frequency
Tips.description: Understand 'wage' often implies a regular payment schedule, like weekly or monthly.
Tips.example: My wage is deposited into my bank account every Friday.

Tips.title: Hourly Context
Tips.description: 'Wage' can imply payment based on hours worked, different from annual salary.
Tips.example: The part-time job offers an hourly wage of $15.

Tips.title: Related to Effort
Tips.description: 'Wage' suggests a direct link between the amount of work and payment received.
Tips.example: Overtime work resulted in an increased wage this week.

senses.de: To start and continue a fight or argument
senses.ex: They waged war against the neighboring country

Tips.title: Conflict Initiation
Tips.description: As a verb, 'wage' involves starting or continuing a conflict or campaign.
Tips.example: Activists waged a campaign to raise awareness.

Tips.title: Persistent Effort
Tips.description: To 'wage' something like a war implies sustained effort over a period of time.
Tips.example: The general vowed to wage a prolonged war if necessary.

senses.de: A fixed regular amount of money paid by an employer
senses.ex: He earns a good wage working in the city

Tips.title: Employment Term
Tips.description: When talking about employment terms, 'wage' often refers to the full pay structure.
Tips.example: His wage includes his base pay plus commissions.

Tips.title: Not Always Cash
Tips.description: 'Wage' doesn't necessarily mean cash payment; it can also mean total compensation.
Tips.example: Her wage package comes with health insurance benefits.

senses.de: Conducted or used for the purpose of carrying on or furthering
senses.ex: A wage battle with less expense

Tips.title: Historical Usage
Tips.description: 'Wage' in archaic contexts often refers to something done with a purpose or intent.
Tips.example: He set forth to wage a noble endeavor.

Tips.title: Bygone Labor Context
Tips.description: In historical times, 'wage' might denote the status and rights of laborers.
Tips.example: Wage laborers of the era fought for fair working conditions.

Compensation.wordDefinition:
Compensation refers to the total amount of money and benefits that an employee receives from their employer in exchange for their work.

Both compensation and wage are applicable in the context of a job or employment.

However, compensation encompasses more than just the wage, as it includes all the other benefits and perks that an employee receives.

Earnings.wordDefinition:
Earnings refers to the money you get from your job or from other sources, like investments or selling something you have made.

If you have a job and you get paid an hourly rate, the money you make from working is your wage. If you also have some investments that earn you money, the total amount of money you make from both your job and your investments is your earnings.

Emolument.wordDefinition:
Emolument refers to any type of payment received by a person for their work or service, and it may include financial and non-financial benefits, such as perks, bonuses, and allowances.

Emolument is more commonly used in a professional or legal context.

Emolument is a broader term that encompasses all types of payments for work, including wages. Wages refer specifically to the monetary compensation paid for the work done.

Emoluments are more commonly used in professional or legal contexts, while wages are associated with manual labor and hourly paid jobs.

Income.wordDefinition:
Income is the total money earned by an individual or household from any source, including wages, salaries, investments, and other sources.

In other words, income is a broader term that includes all sources of money earned, while wages are a specific type of income that is earned by hourly employees based on their hours worked.

Pay.wordDefinition:
Pay refers to the money given to an employee for their work or services. Wage refers to a specific amount of money paid on an hourly basis.

For example, if you work at a restaurant and are paid a flat rate of $10 an hour, that is your wage. If you work at a store and are paid $400 every two weeks, that is your pay.

Pay can refer to both the hourly wage and any additional benefits or bonuses given to an employee.

Remunerate.wordDefinition:
Remunerate means to pay someone for their work or services, often in the form of a salary, bonus, or commission.

Remunerate implies a more comprehensive payment package, including benefits, whereas wages are usually just an hourly or daily pay rate.

Salary.wordDefinition:
Salary and wage refer to the money that a person earns for their work. The main difference is in how they are calculated and when they are paid.

A salary is usually a fixed amount of money that is paid to an employee on a regular basis, such as monthly or annually, regardless of the number of hours worked.

In general, salaries are more commonly used for professional or management-level positions, while wages are more commonly used for jobs that require manual labor or hourly work.

Stipend.wordDefinition:
A stipend is a fixed sum of money paid to someone, usually for a specific purpose or period of time, such as an allowance given to a research assistant or a scholarship received by a student.

Stipends are often paid on a regular basis and may not necessarily be related to the amount of work done by the recipient.

A stipend is a fixed amount of money paid for a specific purpose, while a wage is a payment for work done. Stipends are commonly used in academic and non-profit settings, while wages are used in almost all forms of employment.

quotes.Text: Out of all my friends, I believe I'm the only kid whose dad made us work to cut rebars; we laid bricks in construction sites and did other real work every summer for minimum wage. Our dad said that it's important in the future that when we tell people to dig a hole, that you personally know how long it will take to dig that hole.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Eric Trump

quotes.Text: Fixing a broken immigration system. Protecting our kids from gun violence. Equal pay for equal work, paid leave, raising the minimum wage. All these things still matter to hardworking families; they are still the right thing to do; and I will not let up until they get done.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Barack Obama

quotes.Text: Total war is no longer war waged by all members of one national community against all those of another. It is total... because it may well involve the whole world.
quotes.Title: French Philosopher
quotes.Name: Jean-Paul Sartre

quotes.Text: It is not enough to say we must not wage war. It is necessary to love peace and sacrifice for it.

quotes.Text: How do leaders serve their people? They may pay good wages and treat employees with respect.

quotes.Text: The current minimum wage simply is not supporting Ohio's working families.

quotes.Text: I have never said I was against raising the minimum wage.

quotes.Text: We should wage war not to win war, but to win peace.
